childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1973-1985

You were born the year Roe v. Wade became law, the year the last American troops left Vietnam, and the year everyone discovered their president was a crook. The adults in your life were dealing with Watergate, gas lines, and the slow realization that the American Century might have peaked. You were too young to notice. You were eating Gerber baby food and learning to walk.

Your earliest memories probably involve wood-paneled station wagons, shag carpets, and the particular shade of brown that dominated every living room in America. Your parents smoked inside. Your car had no seatbelts in the back. Your toys were made of lead paint and sharp metal edges. Somehow you survived.

You were seven when the Iranian hostage crisis started. Eight when John Lennon was shot. Nine when Reagan got shot but survived. Ten when E.T. made everyone cry at the movies. You were twelve when the space shuttle Challenger exploded on live television, and your teacher wheeled in the TV cart because Christa McAuliffe was supposed to be inspiring. That lesson was not the one anyone planned.

Your childhood was analog in ways kids today can't fathom. No internet. No cell phones. No caller ID. You had three TV channels, maybe five if you were lucky with the rabbit ears. Entertainment meant playing outside until the streetlights came on. Your parents had no idea where you were for hours at a time, and that was normal.

You were a latchkey kid, or you knew latchkey kids. Both parents working became common during your childhood. You let yourself in after school, microwaved something questionable, and watched cartoons until someone got home. Independence wasn't a parenting philosophy—it was the only option.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Gen X

You're Gen X, born between 1965 and 1980. The forgotten middle child of American generations—too young to be Boomers, too old to be Millennials, perpetually overlooked by marketers and politicians who couldn't figure out how to sell to your skepticism.

Your generation is roughly 65 million people in the US. You were raised by the Silent Generation and early Boomers who believed in institutions that would fail you spectacularly. You watched your parents' marriages collapse at record rates. Divorce wasn't shameful anymore—it was statistically likely.

The defining mood of Gen X is ironic detachment. You learned early that sincerity was dangerous. The hippies sold out. The idealists became stockbrokers. Reagan told you it was morning in America while homelessness exploded and AIDS killed your friends. You responded by not responding. You checked out, tuned out, dropped out—or at least looked like you did.

You're the MTV generation, the slacker generation, the generation that gave us grunge, alternative rock, and the profound insight that everything is stupid and nothing matters, but in a way that's kind of fun. Douglas Coupland wrote a book about you that nobody in your generation actually read, but everyone knows the title.

Gen X entered adulthood just as the rules changed. The job-for-life your parents had? Gone. Pensions? Evaporating. You adapted because adaptation was the only option. You're pragmatic, self-reliant, and deeply suspicious of anyone selling certainty.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

You were born the year The Exorcist traumatized audiences, The Godfather swept the Oscars, and American Graffiti made everyone nostalgic for a 1962 that never quite existed. Pink Floyd released The Dark Side of the Moon—an album that would become permanently fused to late-night dorm room conversations for the rest of time.

Musically, 1973 was transitional. Led Zeppelin was still ruling. Elton John was inescapable. The Carpenters were singing about rainy days and Mondays. Your parents were probably listening to all of it, which means you grew up with classic rock as background radiation.

Your childhood was Star Wars, which hit when you were four and rewired your brain like it rewired everyone else's. You probably had the action figures. You definitely had the lunchbox. By the time Empire Strikes Back came out, you were seven and already a sophisticated consumer of merchandised fantasy.

Your teen years belonged to John Hughes. The Breakfast Club, Sixteen Candles, Ferris Bueller's Day Off—these were your instruction manuals for adolescence. Hughes understood something about suburban teenage ennui that felt like being seen for the first time. You were fourteen when The Breakfast Club came out, and you knew exactly which character you were.

Musically, you came of age with MTV. You watched it transform from a curiosity to a cultural force. You saw Michael Jackson's Thriller video premiere. You witnessed Madonna's entire arc. You were there when hair metal happened, when new wave happened, when grunge killed everything that came before. By the time Nirvana hit in 1991, you were eighteen and ready for someone to articulate your alienation.

Your pop culture touchstones span from disco to grunge—a whiplash journey from optimistic excess to ironic pessimism. You grew up watching culture learn to be cynical.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

You were born the year the Sears Tower became the world's tallest building, Skylab launched, and the first handheld mobile phone call was made (though it would take another decade before anyone but executives could afford one). Technology in 1973 was mainframes and punch cards. Personal computers were a hobbyist dream.

The first video game you probably played was Pong, either at an arcade or on an Atari at a friend's house. Space Invaders arrived when you were five. Pac-Man when you were seven. The arcade was your after-school hangout, eating quarters and developing hand-eye coordination that would prove useful for exactly nothing in adult life.

You were twelve when the Macintosh launched with its iconic 1984 commercial. You were fifteen when the first consumer GPS devices appeared. Eighteen when Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web—though you wouldn't use it for years.

You're the last generation that came of age without the internet. Your college experience involved card catalogs, microfiche, and actually going to the library. If you wanted to know something, you had to look it up in a book. If you wanted to contact someone, you called them or wrote a letter. Information had friction.

You adopted email in your late twenties, probably at work. You got your first cell phone in your mid-to-late twenties—a brick-sized Nokia or Motorola that did nothing but make calls, badly. You learned the internet on dial-up modems, waiting ten minutes for a single image to load.

This gives you a unique perspective. You remember the world before constant connectivity, but you've spent most of your adult life adapting to it. You're fluent in both the old world and the new, which makes you valuable as a translator between generations.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were five months old when the last American combat troops left Vietnam. The war that defined your parents' generation was ending just as you arrived. You don't remember it, but you grew up in its shadow—the draft, the protests, the collective national trauma that nobody wanted to talk about.

You were one when Nixon resigned. Watergate was the background noise of your infancy. By the time you were old enough to understand, 'I am not a crook' was a punchline, and trusting the government was something naive people did.

You were six during the energy crisis. Gas lines. Odd-even rationing. Your parents complaining about OPEC. The post-war abundance that Boomers grew up with was over, and you learned early that resources were finite and the future was uncertain.

You were twelve when Challenger exploded. That one stuck. Your whole school was watching. Christa McAuliffe was supposed to prove that space was safe, accessible, democratic. Instead, you watched her die on live television at 11:39 AM on a Tuesday in January.

You were sixteen when the Berlin Wall fell. Eighteen when the Soviet Union collapsed. The Cold War—the existential threat that shaped your entire childhood—just... ended. No nuclear apocalypse. No World War III. Just a quiet implosion and the promise of a 'peace dividend' that never materialized.

You were twenty-seven during 9/11. Old enough to have adult responsibilities, young enough to have your worldview permanently altered. You watched the towers fall and knew nothing would be the same. The wars that followed would be your generation's wars—fought largely by people younger than you, but authorized by people older.

You were thirty-five during the 2008 financial crisis. Old enough to have a mortgage, a 401(k), something to lose. You watched half of it evaporate. You recovered, probably, but the lesson stuck: nothing is safe.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

You entered the workforce in the early 1990s, during a recession that taught you job security was a myth. The corporate loyalty your parents expected? Already evaporating. Companies that promised lifetime employment started doing 'restructuring,' which was a polite word for throwing people overboard.

You watched Boomers ahead of you clog the promotion pipeline. The same people who told you to work hard and wait your turn never actually moved out of the way. You learned to change jobs, change companies, change careers. Job-hopping wasn't disloyalty—it was survival.

The dot-com boom happened in your late twenties. You might have caught the wave, made some money before it crashed in 2000. Or you might have watched from the sidelines as twenty-three-year-olds in hoodies became millionaires on business plans written on napkins. Either way, you learned that wealth was random and capitalism was absurd.

By 2008, you were mid-career when everything collapsed again. You had enough experience to be expensive, which made you a target for layoffs. You had enough runway to recover, unlike younger workers just starting out. But you understood, viscerally, that the system could fail at any moment.

Your generation pioneered the concept of 'work-life balance' because you watched your parents sacrifice everything for companies that laid them off anyway. You're not disloyal—you're realistic. The corporation will never love you back, so why pretend?

Now you're in leadership positions, often managing Millennials and Gen Z workers who baffle you with their demands for 'purpose' and 'flexibility.' You give them what you can because you remember what it was like to be dismissed by people who didn't understand your generation either.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

You learned to date before the internet. You met people at parties, at work, through friends, at bars. If you wanted to ask someone out, you had to do it in person or over the phone, with your stomach churning and no way to preview their response via text.

You wrote letters. Actual letters, on paper, with stamps. You passed notes in class. You waited by the phone—the landline, the one attached to the wall—for calls that might never come. Rejection happened in real-time, without the buffer of a screen.

You're the last generation that grew up without cell phones. This means you know how to be alone. You know how to be unreachable. You know what it's like to leave the house and actually disappear for a few hours. This is a superpower that younger generations will never have.

Your generation got married later than your parents but earlier than Millennials. You probably married in your late twenties or early thirties. If you divorced—and about half of you did—you did it without the humiliation of social media commentary.

Your communication style is direct because you learned to communicate when bandwidth was limited. You don't send twelve texts when one phone call will do. You find email more efficient than Slack. You're mildly annoyed by people who text 'hey' and then make you wait for the actual message.

Your friendships are probably fewer but deeper than younger generations'. You didn't accumulate five hundred Facebook friends—you maintained a handful of real relationships. Your best friends from college are still your best friends. You're suspicious of anyone with too many social connections to maintain them authentically.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

You came of age during the stagflation of the late '70s, the excess of the '80s, the recession of the early '90s, the dot-com bubble, and the 2008 collapse. Your financial worldview is basically 'prepare for the worst because the worst keeps happening.'

You're the generation that got 401(k)s instead of pensions. This was sold as freedom—control your own retirement! In practice, it meant you've spent your adult life trying to become an amateur investment manager while hoping the stock market doesn't crash right before you retire.

You probably own a home, or you did before 2008. You bought during a saner market than today's, when houses cost three to four times your annual salary instead of ten times. If you held on, you've built equity. If you got caught in the foreclosure crisis, you're still recovering.

Your relationship with money is pragmatic, not aspirational. You're not trying to get rich—you're trying to not be poor. You max out your retirement contributions because you don't trust Social Security to exist when you need it. You keep an emergency fund because you've learned that emergencies are not exceptional—they're regular.

You've been responsible for your own financial security in a way your parents never were, and you're exhausted by it. The idea that you can't just trust institutions to take care of things—that you have to personally optimize every financial decision—is a burden your generation invented and your kids will inherit.

You're probably doing okay, statistically. Gen X has accumulated more wealth than Millennials at the same age, though less than Boomers. But 'okay' feels precarious. One medical emergency, one job loss, one economic collapse, and the whole thing falls apart. You know this because you've seen it happen.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your generation's ironic detachment, which served you well in the Reagan years, has calcified into something less useful. You're so practiced at not caring that sometimes you actually don't care—about politics, about institutions, about collective action. Your learned helplessness became actual helplessness.

You pride yourself on self-reliance, but this can tip into dismissing people who need help. You figured it out without a safety net, so why can't everyone else? This ignores that the game has gotten harder. Today's twenty-five-year-old faces worse economics than you did, and telling them to 'just work harder' misses the point.

You're skeptical of enthusiasm to the point of being unable to get enthusiastic yourself. Everything has to be hedged, qualified, served with a side of irony. This makes you bad at advocacy. You can't fight for a cause if you can't admit you care about it sincerely.

Your generation's independence means you're bad at asking for help, which means you suffer in silence more than necessary. Therapy was stigmatized when you were young. You learned to 'deal with it' instead of getting support. Some of you still think that's a virtue.

You've accepted too much as unchangeable. You watched systems fail and concluded that systems always fail, so why bother fixing them? This pragmatic nihilism means you sometimes don't show up when showing up matters. Voter turnout, civic engagement, collective organizing—Gen X is underrepresented in all of it.

Your relationship with technology is complicated. You adopted it late enough to see it as a tool rather than an extension of self, which gives you perspective. But it also means you sometimes underestimate its importance. You dismiss things as 'just online' when 'online' is increasingly where everything happens.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (1993-2003): You entered adulthood during a recession and came out the other side into the tech boom. You were old enough to remember rotary phones and young enough to become fluent in email. You probably job-hopped more than your parents approved of. You figured out that nobody was going to hand you a career—you had to build one yourself, often sideways.

Your 30s (2003-2013): You were settling into adulthood when 9/11 hit, resetting everything. The 2000s were your family-building years, if you built a family. The 2008 crash tested whatever stability you'd achieved. You lost a job, or a house, or half your retirement savings. You rebuilt, because that's what you do. You got through it without expecting anyone to save you.

Your 40s (2013-2023): You became invisible. Marketers targeted Millennials. Politicians courted Boomers. You kept showing up to work, raising your kids, and paying your mortgage while everyone argued about avocado toast and participation trophies. This was probably your peak earning decade, though 'peak' still felt precarious. You started thinking seriously about retirement and feeling anxious about whether you'd ever get there.

Your 50s (2023-2033): You're here now, or entering soon. Your kids are leaving, if you had them. Your parents are aging or gone. You're in the prime of your career but tired in ways that don't fully recover with a vacation. You're doing the math on retirement and hoping the numbers work out. This is the decade where you either make peace with the life you've built or make dramatic changes while you still can.

Your 60s and beyond (2033+): Retirement, if you can afford it, will be different from your parents'. You'll probably work longer—not because you want to, but because the math requires it. Social Security will exist, probably, but won't be enough. You'll rely on whatever you've managed to save in thirty years of 401(k) contributions. Healthcare costs will be your biggest expense. You'll watch younger generations struggle with problems you tried to warn them about, and they'll ignore you the same way you ignored the warnings from generations before.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

You're part of a birth cohort of roughly 3.1 million people born in 1973. The entire Gen X generation is about 65 million people in the US, making it the smallest of the modern generations—wedged between the massive Boomer and Millennial cohorts.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964), you're their cleanup crew. You got the jobs they didn't want, the economy they damaged, and the institutions they broke. Boomers got free college and affordable housing. You got tuition inflation and the beginning of the housing crisis. Boomers got pensions. You got 'individual responsibility.' They had the luxury of idealism. You had the necessity of pragmatism.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996), you're similar but more cynical. You both entered a broken economy, but you entered it earlier and with lower expectations. Millennials believed they'd been cheated out of something. You never expected much to begin with. They wanted to change the system. You wanted to survive it.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012), you're practically from a different planet. They've never known a world without the internet, without smartphones, without constant connectivity. You remember all of it arriving. They think you're old. You think they're exhausting. You're probably both right.

Your life expectancy is roughly 77-79 years, slightly higher than Millennials due to lower 'deaths of despair' rates. Gen X is pragmatic about health the same way it's pragmatic about everything—you know you need to exercise and eat vegetables, and you mostly do it without making it a lifestyle brand.

Financially, Gen X holds about 30% of US wealth, which is more than Millennials but less than Boomers at the same age. You're the 'sandwich generation,' caring for aging parents while supporting adult children who can't afford to launch. Your retirement is funded by whatever you managed to save yourself. Nobody's coming to help.

Your greatest contribution might be what you didn't do: you didn't burn it down. You maintained institutions through sheer stubborn endurance. You kept showing up. Whether that was heroic or complicit depends on who's asking.
